You want everyone to have the same field of view. If you give people with a 4:3 aspect ratio the same screen height, the result will be a narrower field of view; if you do the same for someone with a 21:9 aspect ratio, they'll end up with a wider field of view.
If you fix width instead, then people with a 4:3 ratio would end up with a higher vertical FOV and people with a 21:9 aspect ratio would have a narrower vertical FOV.
The solution they implemented is to letterbox. You put everything at a 16:9 ratio, and you put black rectangles on the portions of the screen outside of that field of view. Thus, a 4:3 ratio will have black boxes on the top and bottom, to create a 16:9 FOV in the middle of the screen, while a 21:9 screen will have black rectangles on the far left and right of the screen, restricting the field to a central 16:9 ratio field.
You could make it so that no screen FOV is better than 16:9 by simply making all other screen resolutions worse, but this leads to the problem that people who want to play on a different aspect ratio monitor will be worse off. You don't want people's monitors' aspect ratio to give them a competitive advantage.
This isn't an issue for a single player game.

The diagonal FOV IS the same on all monitors. The game displays a 16:9 field of view on these monitors. *All the monitors have the exact same field of view.*
The way it accomplishes this is via letterboxing.
I have a 16:10 monitor. What it does is create a small black rectangle on the top and bottom of the screen. This gives me exactly the same view as a 16:9 monitor, with wasted space (the black letterboxes) on the top and bottom.
Thus I see exactly the same thing as someone would see with a 16:9 monitor in the space between the black bars. In fact, it is pretty much exactly the same size and shape as my 1080p monitor (I have a 1200p monitor, so the display field is in fact a 1080p display field).
The same is true on 4:3 monitors. It creates those black boxes at the top and bottom, thereby reducing the fraction of the screen which is used, but the portion of the screen which is used is displayed at a 16:9 ratio. This gives them exactly the same field of view as someone using a 16:9 monitor.
On a 21:9 monitor, it instead puts the rectangles on the edges of the screen. This again restricts the field of view to a 16:9 ratio, giving you the exact same field of view as anyone else.
If you display the screen at full height on a 4:3 monitor, you'd be reducing the field of view of the player; this happens in some older games. To avoid this issue, they have it display in the way that it does.
Likewise, a 21:9 monitor would give a wider field of view for the same height, so they crop it.

It also depends on some other factors as well; I'm a Euromutt, for instance, with ancestry from basically all of Northern and Western Europe, and even some Eastern Europe. Races are simply population groups on a very macro level. Different population groups are related to varying extents. People in all places have variable skin tones, but their skin tones end up falling within a certain range, barring rare mutations like albinism. Italians have quite light to pretty tan skin, for instance, but they don't have like, really dark skin.
And as you go from the north end of Europe down to North Africa, you see gradually darkening skin tones. There's mixture between adjacent populations, resulting in gene flow between them.
This creates what is known as a ["cline"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cline_(biology)) - a continuous variation in some biological characteristic.
A lot of what defines the "big" races is discontinuities in such clines, generally because of geographic isolation.
When you look at the "big races", what you're really seeing are large groups of population groups which are generally separated from other groups of population groups by some sort of geographic barrier which greatly reduced the amount of interbreeding between population groups - Amerindians were separated by the ocean, as were the Australonesians. Africans were separated from Eurasians by the Sahara Desert. East Asians and Europeans were separated by the deserts and mountains of Central Asia, the jungles of South Asia, as well as sheer geographic distance.
The thing is, these groups are not 100% distinct - there is always some intermixing between population groups along the edges. If you look at [this](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/Rosenberg_1048people_993markers.jpg), you can see some of that - there's some small amount of European ancestry in some African groups. The Indo-European groups in the Middle East have some African admixture. The Indo-European groups in Central and South Asia have some East Asian heritage (look at the Hazara and Uygur in particular), while the East Asians also have some Indo-European admixture. The Australonesians have some East Asian in them. Some of the Amerindian groups show obvious signs of their recent East Asian heritage. The more closely you look at people's genes, the more you can tell that at least some gene flow occurs a great deal of the time.
This is most obvious in North Africans - Egyptians, for instance, did a lot of historical commerce with Nubia to the South, and consequently there was gene flow across the Sahara Desert along the Nile. Likewise, on the other end of Africa, there was gene flow around coastline.
These sort of intermediate populations exist along the fringes between population groups.
As such, there are basically "groups", and then there are intermediate groups which sort of fall on the edges.
Or are there?
The argument in the field, as far as the actual science goes, is whether such "intermediate groups" are properly seen as such - basically as a mixture between two distinct population groups - or if they are better seen as part of a greater, more gradual cline between groups.
In other words, if you go south from Norway to South Africa, are you seeing a continuous, slow slope in genetic variation, as people gradually change as you go further and further south, or do you generally see a slow change, then a sudden much faster change as you hit an intermediate group, then a return to a much slower change at a new normal on the other side?

Race, ultimately, doesn't matter much from an empirical point of view - individual characteristics vary immensely within each race. There are tall Asians and there are short Swedes. Genetic markers are basically detectable points of genetic variation, which are found via various methods.
When we talk about population groups, what you see is [genetic clustering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetic_clustering) - basically, you look at a bunch of genetic markers (a large number of them), and then you look at variations with their distributions between groups.
Each population group has a different distribution of genetic markers within its population. Many genetic markers show up in *all* groups, but they don't show up at the same rate. Basically, in one group, you might have a 75% chance of having a marker, while in another group, you might have only a 25% chance of having said marker. Thus, said marker isn't a great indication that you are part of one population group or another.
However, if you take a large number of genetic markers, and look at their distribution, you can start to see patterns. If you look at, say, a hundred markers, then suddenly the randomness of the individual markers matters less. After all, you'll roll a 6 on a six-sided die 1/6th of the time, but the odds of rolling nothing but 6s on 100 die is very small indeed.
By looking at a probabilistic distribution of genetic markers, you can figure out whether or not groups "hang together" so to speak - they'll have more genetic markers in common with each other than other groups - if they are a genetically distinct population group, they'll have a distinct set of markers. If they're not, then they'll cluster in with other groups.
You can look at major, top-level population clusters or you can cut things down to a finer level by looking at smaller ones. [At K=5](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/Rosenberg_1048people_993markers.jpg) (basically, splitting the world up into the five largest clusters), you see sub-Saharan Africans, Indo-Europeans, East Asians, Australonesians, and Amerindians.

I don't get why people get upset about this anyway. Reality doesn't change just because you pretend it doesn't exist, and it isn't like genetic clustering means some group is inherently superior or inferior.
Human genetic variation and gene clustering is a real thing and it isn't particularly controversial; the main argument from a scientific point of view is the debate over the importance of genetic clines and the overall level of between-group variation and hybridization (i.e. the debate between people like Rosenberg and Xing).

Race has no consistent biological basis. Traits are linked to heritage and biology, yes, BUT the variation of those traits within race categories is often greater than the variation between categories.
This is completely untrue, actually.
*Genetic* variation is greater within groups than between groups. However, a lot of genetic variation is on "junk DNA", and moreover, this is misleading for reasons I'll go into below.
However, in terms of phenotypic traits, this isn't true at all - depending on the trait.
Some traits you see much more within-group variation than between-group variation - a good example of this would be height. If you look at people from various groups, you'll find immense variation in height. There is some inter-group variation (some groups *are* especially short or tall) but overall, you see tons of height variation and most groups fall well within the bell curve for each other.
However, other traits (such as skin color) show a lot more between-group variation than within-group variation - this is why it is very easy (generally speaking) to identify someone of a specific racial ancestry just by looking at them. Indeed, physical anthropologists can determine someone's race by looking at their bones pretty accurately.,
This would obviously be impossible if race was merely a social construct.
If you actually dig into the science of the subject, you'll find out that the idea that race is a social construct is, ironically, itself a social construct - it is an unscientific ideological push by certain people, as well as a deliberate miscasting of the science, covering an actual "real" argument over genetic clines and the importance thereof.
What you see within various population groups is distributions of genetic variations. But if you look at humans and *chimpanzees*, you can find a lot of genetic variations people share with *chimpanzees* that we don't share with other humans.
But clearly, there is a huge gulf between humans and chimpanzees!
The cause is threefold. First, non-coding (often referred to as "junk") DNA is not strongly selected for. Thus, variations within this aren't going to really matter, so the fact that they vary a lot is irrelevant - there's not really any selective pressure there, so there's going to be a lot of variation and gene drift. Secondly, there are things which don't have strong or have conflicting selective pressure on. The result of these is that you see them across a lot of population groups - stuff like blood types are a good example of this. While there is some weak selective pressure on blood types, you can find members of the major blood types within most population groups.
As a result, only a relatively small fraction of the genome is going to have strong selective pressure placed on it, and many of those are going to correspond to the most important expressed traits. And for these traits to reliably diverge, you generally need to have differential selective pressure placed on them - i.e. pressure coming from one direction for one group, and another direction for another. Skin color is a good example of this - there's a fairly strong bit of selective pressure for darker skin around the tropics and lighter skin around the poles. Thus, you see people in tropical areas who have darker skin and people around the poles who have lighter skin. Obviously this is not uniform, but it is a general trend you can see across population groups.
This is why skin color varies so much, incidentally - there's a relatively high level of selective pressure on it, and it is relatively easy to accumulate all of the "dark skinned" alleles, because skin color is not controlled by a single gene, but a large number of genes.
This means that any individual may have one or more alleles for "dark skin" or "light skin", even though they have the opposite color of skin.
If, however, you look at the group as a whole, and measure the prevalence of relevant genetic markers, you'll see a clear trend towards light-skinned groups having a lot of light-skinned alleles and dark-skinned groups having a lot of dark-skinned alleles.
And indeed, many human traits are like this - polygenic traits that are affected by more than one gene.
If you take lots of genetic markers, and look at them together, you find that you end up with [stuff like this.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a1/Rosenberg_1048people_993markers.jpg) Rather than seeing random variation, you see clustering of variation.
While any individual genetic marker may not be particularly predictive of your population group of origin (your "race", if you will), when you look at the genome as a whole, you can determine someone's population of origin with quite a bit of accuracy, and you can look at populations and see how they are distinct from one another. You can also see that groups aren't "pure"; there is some admixture in all of them, and there are also clearly intermediate groups between population groups.

This is really where the main debate is within the science.

Inflation is the measure of the increase in the price of goods from year to year. There is no such thing as a single inflation number; it is an estimate.
The problem is that the idea that incomes have only gone up by $3900/year since 1990 is an obvious lie, and is really a great indication of why the CPI (which is the metric in this case) is garbage.
So here's the deal: there are multiple inflationary indicies. CPI and IPD are two of the better known ones - the Consumer Price Index and the Implicit Price Deflator. They're calculated by different government agencies for different purposes; the IPD is the inflation adjustment used to calculate productivity increases, for instance.
The problem is that neither inflationary index is actually designed to measure long-term inflation. CPI, for instance, is calculated on a month to month basis; long-term inflation is simply "calculated" by multiplying together smaller changes and getting a bigger one.
The problem is you can't actually do this; it leads to wildly inaccurate results.
The reason is that inflation is calculated by taking a bundle of goods at one point in time, then taking that same bundle of goods at another point in time and calculating how much the price of that bundle of goods has changed. Obviously, your choice of goods in said bundle of goods affects the calculated inflation rate, as does your weighting of the prices of said goods.
The problem is that when you start looking at long periods of time, you come to the obvious and immediate realization that you cannot actually do this. While a bag of rice is a bag of rice, a car is not a car; a car from 1970 is not equivalent to a car from 1990, which is not equivalent to a car from 2017.
This is one of the ways in which things go completely wrong. The average price of a car has approximately doubled since 1990. But if you compare a 1990 car to a 2017 car, the 1990 car is vastly worse. If you look at the bottom level 2017 car, the cheapest one - the Nissan Versa - it is a vastly better car than the equivalent 1990 cars. Indeed, if you compare it to equivalent vehicles from 1990, you find that you simply cannot get a vehicle with a lot of its features from 1990 because they didn't *exist* yet.
The 1991 Geo Metro LSI had worse features and yet still cost $11,121 for something with [pretty minimal features](https://www.cars.com/reviews/los-angeles-timess-view-1420689068837/) - fewer than even a bottom-rung vehicle like the Versa has today.

The problem with such "adjustments" is that it assumes that marijuana is not a contributing factor to them; i.e. if marijuana users are more likely to be in demographics which get in more crashes and use more alcohol, it may well be that part of the reason why those demographics are more likely to have accidents is use of marijuana. In other words, your adjustment may be adjusting for the very factor you're trying to measure.
The correct way of doing this is to compare people with and without marijuana in their systems and looking at their relative car crash rates within a given demographic, not doing such gross demographic adjustments.
Numerous studies have found that marijuana - and especially marijuana in combination with alcohol - impairs people's driving ability. The fact that it shows up disproportionately often in car crash victims suggests that there's probably a link.
